text: today on the caucus political editor
richard stephenson on the president's
wide-ranging press conference good
morning everybody have a seat please and
kate sir nikki answers reader questions
about the Tea Party's clout in 2012
hopefully leaders at a certain point
rise to the occasion and they do the
right thing for the American people and
that's what I expect to happen this time
call me naive President Obama covered a
lot of territory in his news conference
but he was really pushing two big
messages out there the first one was on
the negotiations over the federal budget
deficit and the need to raise the debt
ceiling and there he really pressed the
Republicans harder than he has so far
too except that they're going to have to
include some kind of tax increases in
any deal so the bottom line is this any
agreement to reduce our deficit is going
to require tough decisions and balanced
solutions I think it's only fair to ask
an oil company or a corporate jet owner
that has done so well to give up that
tax break that no other business enjoys
he also talked a lot about the economy
which is clearly the issue that more
than any other is likely to determine
the outcome of his reelection race his
real message on the economy was please
be patient every day that weighs on
every minute of every day that weighs on
the president was also asked several
times about one of the big news stories
of the moment which is gay marriage he
did not go as far as to say that he
would support gay marriage now he listed
a litany of steps that his
administration has taken emphasized that
gay equality would in the end when out
but stopped short of explicitly backing
gay marriage I'm not going to make news
on that today good try though the
president has to timetables in mind that
he was dealing with here one is the next
five or six weeks
which is going to be consumed by the
negotiations on Capitol Hill over the
debt limit increase he's also though
looking to November 2012 and keeping his
eye on the idea that he needs to
persuade the American people that the
economy is getting better that he
understands what it's like out there
that's a tricky thing for him people are
going to begin to harden their
perceptions of him as a president and be
looking at the Republican alternatives
but he has the advantage right now of
none of the Republican candidates really
having caught fire but still he needs to
persuade people that the economy is
getting better and the message of asking
for patience is only going to work for
him for so long hi I'm Kate sir Nikki
with the New York Times I wrote the
article in today's paper about how the
Tea Party which had so much influence in
the midterm elections is now trying to
transition from campaigning to governing
and is finding a few difficulties we
took some of your questions about the
Tea Party online and now we're going to
try to answer them first question comes
from someone identifying him or herself
as furious and USA why in the world is
so much attention given to this fake
astroturf group funded by right-wing
millionaires to appear like a grassroots
group we got a lot of questions like
this one first thing I would say is the
Tea Party did not start as an astroturf
group it was genuinely a grassroots
movement when it began you don't need a
lot of money to start a tea party need
people who are angry with a lot of signs
and that again doesn't take a lot of
money a lot of these right-wing groups
like Americans for Prosperity and
FreedomWorks did seize on that movement
when it hit the streets and they're now
trying to Train it in favor of some of
the legislation that they're pushing
across the country in particular
anti-union legislation so what they're
doing is they're paying to train these
groups they're paying them in some cases
is lobbyists as in today's story but
it's important to sort of draw a
distinction from what they are and what
they're not doing so freedom works which
is the group that we talked about in the
story today is indeed pushing for the
school choice legislation it's
interesting though to note that the Koch
brothers who are often sort of
considered in this big evil force behind
the Tea Party are not involved in the
Pennsylvania fight in fact they looked
at the Pennsylvania fight and some tea
party activists who are opposed to the
school choice bill in Pennsylvania
said we don't want you to get involved
and so Americans for Prosperity which is
the Koch brothers group has actually
stayed out of that fight they're not
pushing the legislation so they are
genuinely listening to the grassroots
group on the ground next one comes from
Urbana Illinois why is the New York
Times spending time examining this group
this kind of media coverage is exactly
what makes the Tea Party appear to be
more powerful than they actually are in
exit polls after the midterm elections 4
and 10 voters said that they were
supporters of the Tea Party movement so
I think actually media organizations
have an obligation to examine where this
where this sympathy is coming from where
the support is coming from and what it's
all about but as the story today shows
the Tea Party is not always as
monolithic as it's often described it's
not always coherent or even united in
its governing goals as we head into
another campaign it's important to
understand how well the Tea Party will
be able to organize itself and how much
influence it's really going to have
going forward
